response.answer_text: I didn’t write for the first five years since I wanted to write. I thought I would churn out the all time best one piece article that’s gonna shake the world. I would think up the next harry potter idea or next Game of thrones series and just kill it. I waited five years. Nothing happened. I never did anything. The golden moment never came. The right time never came. I thought I had to think up of something “worth” writing about. I thought people want to listen to my opinions. I started writing opinions. And nobody gave a shit. My opinions aren’t what makes me unique as an individual. I didn’t realize that. My experiences are what makes me unique. My experiences with BITS, my experience with depression, my experience with the girl I got a date with is what makes me different. When I started sharing those experiences than it actually started adding value to other people’s lives. They could relate to the experiences. They could relate to my struggles. The way I handled those struggles added value to other people. I started my blog cum podcast Finding Zarathustra with the same aim in mind. I would talk to different people trying to gather their experiences and share it with everyone. These interesting people at my college would never otherwise come and share anything with the world. They might share their opinions but never their experiences. Something which is really valuable but they don’t realize. So how do you start writing?Write about that day when your mom kicked you out of the house , about that day when you proposed to your girlfriend or about the time when you went for an internship but were made to do dumb shit. Don’t write opinions. Nobody cares what you think of Donald trump. It doesn’t add value to other people’s lives. That’s not what makes you unique. Your experiences make you unique. So my opinion on writing is not to write opinions.

I assume that you are young. If so, I am really pleased that you are interested in writing. To be able to write well will give you more advantages in the future than I can even think of. And if you can write well, you can think well. There are a couple of things to think about. Number one is to read. Read books, read magazines, read articles, read those magnificent answers on Quora. Pick subjects that you enjoy and read, read, read. While you are reading pay particular attention how the author describes things. How does those words that the author put on paper provide an image in your mind? How did it get from your paper to your mind? The author says something well, and you can imagine it perfectly. Pay attention to to how the author does this. Number two. Start writing by describing things. Simple things. It doesn’t have to be written well, but it must be written. ‘I looked out the window and saw the grass. The grass was green with a little bit of brown mixed in. And there was a sidewalk’. A short descriptive passage. Maybe tomorrow you will look out the window and notice something else. ‘The grass needs mowing. There is a little lump of something there. Uh oh. I think it is dog poop. It must Mrs. Smith’s dog from next door. My father is going to be mad.’ Next, instead of looking out the window at your lawn, just imagine what your lawn looks like. Roam across and around and through your lawn in your mind. Let your mind explore your lawn. ‘If I shrunk my self real tiny and walked through the grass it would be like I was in a jungle. It would be scary but fun too. Mrs. Smith’s dog poop would look like a stinky mountain. What if I saw an ant? A grasshopper? A bug? Would it look like a monster?’ And so it starts. By observing and describing what you observe you are training your mind to see things — things you normally don’t see. You will look at a lamp on a table and notice that it needs dusting and that it has funny designs on it. You will look at your unmade bed and discover that if you look at those twisted covers and sheets in a certain way they look like waves on the ocean in a storm. Or maybe look at it another way you can see an animal, a sheep you think. And you wonder how a sheep got in your bed. Your mind learns to explore. When you mind explores, your writing improves and explores. Don’t worry too much about writing a story that makes sense. Don’t even try to write a story. Describe things. The describe how you feel about things. ‘The grass makes me feel sad. I guess it is because it is so plain and flat. There is no excitement or fun in my lawn. Maybe if there was a tiny dinosaur lost in the grass jungle. Oh that’s stupid. But you know if Marvin, that is his name, could make it to the sidewalk then he would know where he was. Maybe I should look out the window again and see where he is and where he should go. With Marvin I’m not sad anymore.’ Don’t worry too much about making sense. Don’t worry about punctuation and any of those rules. Just write about what you see and what you imagine and what you feel. Describe stuff. When you get to where you can write a lot of words about the simplest things, you are a writer. Most people cannot do that. You have trained your mind and your eyes to see things and your talent to write it all out. This is how I would advise you to start writing as a beginner. Go for it.

You’ve already begun! Start by asking the question “How can I get started writing?” on Quora. You will get a few answers. Read them. and then gnore them. After you wake up, think about your dream last night. Sit at a desk with a computer or a pad and paper. Write down what you dreamt about. See which of your dreams interest you into spending time with them. Work on turning those thoughts into a story which has a beginning, a middle and an end. Write the beginning down. Revise it. Now go for the middle. Revise it. Now try to come up with an ending. Look at what you’ve written. It’s a good start, but not worth showing to someone. Go over it again, and change it till you’re happy. Sit on it for a day and then re-read it. It isn’t that good. Rewrite it. Show it to someone who will lie and say that they like it Now show it to two or three people with no emotional investment in you or your writing. They will give you some advice. If two strangers give you the same advice — make your story shorter or longer—- take it. Rewrite it again. Rewrite it again just in case. Go to a writing conference that has “pitch sessions.” Pitch your idea to an agent or publisher. They should also give you advice and promise you that they will get back to you. They’re lying. Rewrite your story again. Now, tell the agent or publisher that you’ve taken their advice. They will tell you to submit your story. If they ask you for money, don’t trust them. Find someone else, perhaps at another writing conference. Send out your story again. It wil be accepted. Write another story. You will have an easier time this time. Submit your story. It will be published. Sell your story to Hollywood. It will be turned into a television eries. Have the producers ruin your story by having a heroine burn down Kings Landing with a dragon. Feel depressed and not write for a few years. Sit at a desk with a computer or a pad and paper… Ask another question on Quora…

No matter what type of writer you are (writing novels, stories, poetry, short tales, quotes, anything to everything), these tips will help you improve your writing skills. Be Original - At first, this point might not come in your way. But when you've spent a lot time on writing, you will face the writer's block. This means that there will come a point of time where you lack ideas to write and you wish to copy (plagiarise) someone's work. Don't plagiarise! You will get pass through and you would write even better. Just be original. You know the consequences of not being original.Read - As much as you can. Read when free, read when busy, read when sick, read when healthy, read when stuck while writing, read when writing isn't that big of an issue. In short, read a lot. You might have seen this point almost on every answer on Quora! Still wondering why?Cut Using Adverbs ‘very' & ‘really' - This is something every writer finds the most difficult to do.The weather is very hot..You look very pretty …Very is very important word....This is really amazing!I'm really honest…See? How a sentence becomes ordinary by using ‘very’ & ‘really' almost all time? Cut them. Improve your vocabulary, learn new better words that fit into your writings.   These will certainly help you. Write when writing, edit when editing - This point works wonders (not literally wonders though :D). Editing is an important and interesting part of writing. You refine, redo, reinvent your work. But make it a habit to write everything down now and edit it later.When the deadline is approaching, you have to finish and submit your work, right? So complete your writing first to make you have something to submit. Time left? Start editing!Remember, you have to show your writing, not your editing. So write and then edit it. Don't be in a rush to edit. The ideas you generated will be gone and you will get stuck editing. Write what you would like reading/Breaks - As simple as the title. Keep in mind while writing, “is this what I would appreciate, admire, adore when reading?” If yes, go on. If no, take a break.Listen music in your break. Get motivated to write.Read whatever interests you.Watch TV, movies, videos on anything you love.Your break can last from 1 minute to your entire life (not that long). You will get new, better, creative, innovative ideas. Don't worry. This happens to every writer. It will happen to you too. I guess this is enough for you to know about writing. Some people tell you to just write. It’s true, you should open your text editor and write what made you want to write a book in the first place. But if you tried that, there’s a pretty good chance you got stuck. So, other people advise you to plan first. That’s also good advice, but then you start hearing about plot, pace, action-reaction, scene structure, main vs. secondary characters, climax, and by inciting incident your head already starts spinning. Both of these tips are good tips, but since you’re just starting out, both are rather intimidating. So I’m going to suggest something a little bit different. Pick a situation. It can be anything. Choose a situation where there’s a character, and they’re somewhere in a setting, doing their thing. That’s all. Now, think about a problem, a conflict that’ll get into the picture. It can be something small or something big. For example, I picked a situation where my dancer character is dancing as usual. Then, she twists her ankle. Now, you might say, ok, she’ll recover. That’s where you go ahead and continue to keep the problem alive. For example, there’s a big performance next week that’s very, very important to her. But if she can’t be there, what can she do? Well, maybe she can make sure the show won’t run on its scheduled date… Somehow… You keep the problem alive, and the story stays alive. I explain it thoroughly here:  The reason I’m suggesting this to you is because this method is simple and it’ll be easier for you to start this way. The concept is simple in your mind when you’re writing, and you can always keep going with it. After you’ve written some things, remember the previous advice: Just write, because overthinking can kill your writing. And try planning, because it may help you not get lost. Keep in mind there are many writers who don’t plan at all. It’s a matter of personal preference and writing style. Another thing I can suggest is writing prompts, meaning, small ideas that you can develop into your own story. The internet is full of them, look it up in google. People in our time have a wonderful resource in being able to write on computers, move chunks of prose around, save various versions, and avoid the old fashioned process of cut-and-paste, which used to require real paper, scissors, and glue. But we still have the task of getting it down, however randomly and poorly worded. You cannot edit and improve if you have a blank page. First, write down your ideas and words, any old which way, so long as you get them down. Then you can restructure your story or essay, and polish it up. Once you have something you regard as a finished piece, cut the word count by at least 20%. It will, believe me, be 100% better. Read it out loud to yourself to help you find lapses in continuity, bad wording, or “missing links” — those places where you understand your chain of reasoning but no one else will. You might also have a friend read it and ask you questions. Buy “The Elements of Style.” Skip other books about the process of writing. They are useful, most of them, but are best for more advanced writers, and can slow you down in the necessary task of putting the #$@&%*! words on the #$@&%*! paper. You should spend at least four times as much time writing as reading, and beware of falling into the Editing Zone, where like chewing your cud, no fresh grass ever enters the cow. 1,000 new words a day is a good goal to keep you out of the trap of too much reading, or editing the same 24,000 words for a decade and never actually getting your heroine past her first night in the ancient castle. Poor girl, her feet are getting cold. Get her out of there. Becoming a good writer will take years. But you can become a better writer, faster, by putting effort into making each piece as good as you can. Finally, read a lot. (But less than you write.) Shorter collections like essays, comedy, poetry, short stories and so on will show you how to tighten and streamline your writing and make it effective. Plus, you’ll enjoy the reading, if nothing else as a welcome break from the writing.

Think of writing as a muscle that you strengthen over time by practising. It's simple as that: just write. Obviously not helpful, but you need to expose yourself to different ways of writing so you can really find what you want from it all. This also boosts your confidence with each new project you put yourself into. It'll be very very hard all along the way: You cannot start a journey of this magnitude and expect immediate success, or stardom for that matter. Writing is an art. All artists must SUFFER. But you may enjoy it. There are a few mentionable factors that you must consider: Peer reviews: You need feedback on your writing; constructive feedback. This can be achieved by having mentors, or having your own group of writers. More effectively is posting online where strangers get to criticize you from their couches.Reading: Obviously.Planning: If you have a complete plot for what you want to write, you might as well have 80% of the workload done. The other 20% is just jotting it down. Just... This will take care of plot holes and writer's block, and if you can get to the ending, you're technically a winner. :)Consistency: Is the most critical value in writing, otherwise you'll keep telling your friends about how you've been “writing your first novel for the last decade".You only have so much time on this earth, which means you have only so many articles/books/blogs that you can possibly write before none if matters anymore. So go on: create, write before you can't anymore. It might take you 50000 fanfictions for you to be recognized; it might only take 2 novels. You might never be reknown or famous at all, and all your creations disappear in the abysmal internet, or charred in an attic fire. This broad range of possibilities is a test to the perseverance and passion you have towards an agenda: but isn't it the same in all of life undertakings? :) I hope for you the best in your journey. :)) Sonder.

Read. Write fiction, non-fiction, poetry. Read classics and modern fiction if you want to write fiction. Read good non-fiction writers if you want to write non-fiction. Get a gig writing for a blog or submit to online mags. I started writing before the internet changed the face of books. I wrote, I took classes from community collegee, went to writers’ conferences (you might be able to get a “scholarship” to one if you can’t afford it) and I wrote every day. Again, read. Everything. After a couple of semesters of community college courses, after my first writers’ conference, with no degree, I wrote to the editor of a local magazine and then walked in and got a job writing for that magazine. Pretty soon I was writing features. From that I moved onto a local newspaper. I went from writing straight news, ad copy, etc. to writing features for them including cover stories. I learned on the job. I had been writing short stories and poetry since I was a teen. Twenty years after high school I had my regular gig working a regular job and I had to do six hour turnarounds on articles sometimes. (Careful what you wish for.) Again read. Again, write every day and vary what you write so you don’t get caught up just indulging yourself without improving. Look, I am not a household name. Never will be. But I have known hundreds of writers, some of them household names. Most writers ghostwrite, sell articles, edit, teach or whatever to make a buck. A lot have second jobs. Maybe you will be an exception to that rule. I hope so. But writing is rewarding in as much as you can often be proud of what you put out there. I have written some pieces that got letters because readers were moved by what I wrote. So, you know what? I will always have that even if I never have an award-winning novel. At this point, I would not suggest that anyone try to be a writer without getting a degree unless you can talk an editor somewhere into letting you learn on the job. It would be tough, but there you go.

Before all else, you need to just write. Don't write with any particular audience in mind, don't even write with publication in mind, just write. Fiction, poetry, nonfiction, try a little of everything, whatever inspires you. The same goes for reading. In order to pursue writing, you have to figure out what you want/like to write, and the only way to do that is to read, write, and experiment. You also need to remember that, in the beginning, you're probably not going to be spectacular. You'll have potential for sure, but you must hone this potential in order to become a good—let alone great—writer. This will involve lots of practice, lots of feedback, lots of revisions, and lots of scrapped ideas. This can be the most frustrating part of being a writer but, for many, it's also the best. To see yourself get better and better, to see how far you've come and to just immerse yourself in the process of pouring your heart out onto the page and then refining it, gives you an incredible feeling of pride and accomplishment, even before you're ever published. If you're already engaging in that part of becoming a writer and are preparing to proceed to publication, your first step is to do your homework. Find out which publications and which agents would be the best fit for your work and, more importantly, might be looking for something like it. While you're doing this homework, make certain your work is ready to be published; workshop it, get other avid readers to give feedback, because most writers genuinely can't tell the true quality of their work, especially after working with it for days, months, maybe even years. The pursuit of writing is a long and challenging path but also rewarding. It takes time, patience, and perseverance, but so long as you never stop working on your craft, you'll find at least some satisfaction in your work.

What do you want to write? What’s your intended audience? What qualifies you to write on that? For them? You need to have an idea where you want to get before you can start moving toward getting there. From that point forward, you get started writing by… reading — articles, books, whatever on your chosen subject (unless you aim to write books; that’s a whole nother discussion!). Next, you need to settle on a specific topic, and think through — ‘thinking’ by putting notes on paper (or a computer screen) — what you want to write on that topic. Do you need to do research? If so, do it. If you don’t think you do (need to do research), you’re probably wrong! If for no other reason than to confirm what you already know you know, do some research to confirm what you think to be true. Write an outline. If you don’t know how to write an outline, ask a question here. Even after 50+ years as a writer, I still use an outline — sometimes just a mental one, sometimes working from the end back to the beginning: I want to get to Z; To get there, I need to have done Y, and before that, X. Some editors and writing instructors advise that when you think you’re finished with whatever you’re writing (assuming it’s not a book!), take the last paragraph and make it the first one. Though I seldom do that in my blogs, http://Foodtrades.com and TheRewriteDesk.com, I kinda-sorta apply that logic in almost everything I write — except, perhaps, in answers on Quora. Here, it’s sometimes necessary to clarify the question before formulating an answer.

Please also read my 50+ answers on various aspects of writing at http://www.quora.com/Sanjeeva-Shukla/answers/Writing With due apologies for my irreverence, I am yet to come across a great book by guys who've written grammar books or compiled dictionaries!  Well, of course, we need to have just that basic language in place, and the rest depends on how badly we want to write! Honestly, the more critical things that we need for writing well are what all of us already have: a heart that beats for the world around us; and a head that can add a few interesting spins to those beats. I believe a piece of writing gets great because it connects and it works. Great writing is democratic because the writer appears to be one of us. Ornate writing can win us a few gasps but it doesn't usually connect. It reads lovely if you can get it right without going overboard, but nine times on ten, it may just not work.  When language rules our head, thoughts become secondary and we simply bead them into the language for the heck of it. It's like putting the cart before the horse. It's like forgetting to serve food in our silverware during a dinner! When the medium begins overpowering the message, we need to sit up and shake our head, and shake it hard. Yeah, times change, and what's great also changes. But whatever tugs our heart hasn't changed for ages. And it's content that does the trick, not language. sanjivashukla@gmail.comPosted from Quora on BlackBerryZ10

As others have said, just start writing. Know that most of what you produce at first may not be very good. But that’s okay. It’s all practice and the more you practice, the better you will be. If you don’t know what you want to write, pick up a pen or pull up your keyboard and sees what comes out. If you know what you want to write, start writing in that style (every form of writing is different. writing short stories won’t necessarily teach you how to write novels). Watch instructional videos (youtube has them by the thousands), read instructional articles. Write every day. Write what comes to mind even if it feels stupid in the moment. Some of it will make more sense in retrospect and some will not, but you never know until you get it down on paper. Review it, improve it where you can, correct errors you see, give it a good polish. Cut out parts that don’t make sense, don’t need to be there, or drag down the piece. Elaborate on the parts that need elaboration. Rearrange things if necessary. If you’re doing it right, you will be doing it more than once. And then get that writing out there. Answer questions on Quora. Start a blog. Get involved in a discussion board for people writing the same sorts of things you are. Make friends and, above all GET FEEDBACK!!! I cannot overemphasize that. The best way to learn to make yourself a better writer is to listen to what people have said about what you’ve already written. Learn to ignore “this sucks, die in a fire!” type reviews (they will only depress you and most are coming from trolls and assholes more than people who genuinely had a problem with your work). When you get “this is great, write moar!!!” reviews, don’t just smile to yourself and rest on your laurels. Politely ask for details and clarifications about what makes it good, and how it might have been better. And always pay attention to those precious “this could have been better in this way, this way, and this way” reviews. They mean that someone was interested enough by what you just wrote to take the time to give you detailed feedback. And you can take that feedback and use it to self-improve. Write as much as you can. Know you won’t always be able to write in a given day. Don’t let that discourage you. Keep your goals small and know that failing at one isn’t the end of the world. Remember, writing is a process, not a single event. It takes time and repeated applications of effort, over days, weeks, months, sometimes even years. But every bit you write brings you a bit closer to a finished product. And that means that ever word you write, whether you keep it or scrap it, is something to feel good about.

Some of the helpful tips that I’ve gathered over the years are - Observe - Your observation skills, is the first aspect that marks the difference between a writer and a non-writer. For example, the way you describe a person’s eyes should be different from a non-writer, which is possible only when you observe the concerned person more closely as compared to the others.Imagination - Your imaginative skills are as essential as your presentation skills. continuing with the above stated example, a writer would describe a pair of eyes as “an ocean of emotions”, “a reflection of heart”, “hazel coloured dream” and so on, whereas others may be comfortable with just “deep”.Language - You should be proficient in the language you use. Grammatical errors are just not acceptable. You should also make sure to be aware of the intricacies of the subject, for example, what is a poem, what are the kinds of poems, their format, style and many other details.Presentation - How you present your work also holds a great deal of importance. It is human nature to judge the book by its cover or what can be called as the first look. Make sure that the presentation is at par with the content of the book.Content - The content should be well formatted, so that reading is a comfortable process for the readers. The drafting should be taken care of. Every time it is not necessary to make use of gaudy fonts, the written matter should be powerful enough to grab and retain the attention of the readers.Themes - Writing something that has been written by many, or is being written by many, doesn’t sell in the long run. It becomes too mainstream. Choose a theme that you’re well aware of and is unique. That will help you leave a mark on your readers.Just a note - In the present scenario, the number of poetasters has increased indefinitely.

Any writing starts from scratch. Look up a topic, any topic, and put your thoughts and ideas on paper. If you’re new to writing you won’t do great on your first attempt. Nor will you do great on your second or third or even hundredth attempt. But you’ll improve, and you’ll do so considerably. After you’ve written a hundred essays, a thousand pages, a million words, you’ll feel more comfortable with expressing your thoughts in writing. Starting a new piece will be easier and easier because you’ll have years, if not decades, of experience to fall back upon. But even then you won’t feel your writing is good enough. You will see room for improvement. You’ll read a lot, to learn from other people’s writing. You’ll storm through books on writing, books about writing, books with writing. You’ll be able to imitate the greatest authors. But even then you won’t be satisfied. You won’t take well to being someone else’s copy, however grand that someone else might be. You’ll start developing your own style, your own voice. You’ll grow more confident about yourself and your writing. You’ll see more fun in documenting your thoughts on paper. You’ll find more joy at writing and at getting better at it. It’s at this juncture that writing will become your second nature.

Anything big starts with baby steps. To start writing, before anything else, prepare your mind to not compare yourself with any one else. Your writing is a reflection of you, and you are unique. So don’t compare your writing with that of others. Everyone has his or her own way of writing. So also don’t ask for approvals from anyone.After that select good and appropriate platforms to showcase your writing where you can get maximum readers and support. Instagram, Quora or any blog page such as WordPress, Tumblr, etc.Make sure, you choose varied topics. Don’t confine your self to any specific topic. Make material for audience with different topic interests.AND, the easiest part is WRITING. Write your heart out. Stay original and unique.Just follow what your heart says, and you’ll reach your destination. xoxo

I want to start by saying that nothing ISN’T worthwhile. My sister-in-law did a blog for fun and isn’t exactly a great writer. But, she made her blog fun and quirky through her writing and made it to 200k page views in about 10 posts? Anyone’s work is worthwhile. I see everyone is telling you to write. Whilst this is partially true there is something that should be taken way more into consideration. That is reading. Writing is a practice, reading is where you get the knowledge. You don’t read? Well you’re going to struggle to get a grasp for how others write or how you should write for your readers. Writing will help to a limit. I have recently begun writing my novel (and I won’t lie I have got a published short story) so I understand the annoyance/struggles of where you should start writing. A strong opener goes a long way. Start with a question to draw in your reader or something that is so descriptive and inticing that it will give your audiance goosebumps from the first paragraph.Make it clear and not clunky. God, I am a king at clunky writing in my first drafts. My writing style is unique and with that follows the clunkiest of clunky texts. It is so important to have something easy to read that doesn’t detract from quality.Also questions always leads to answers and answers always leads to ideas. For example, ask yourself, what am I writing and why am I writing it? There are people out there who can assess your work if you’re worried about being a lack lust writer (though, I wouldn’t let something like this sway you.) What are you writing? And I wish you any luck!

“Your cousin was killed.” I was working as a full-time maintenance manager in a manufacturing plant. It was a hot day like many others in the Northeast region of Brazil and at lunchtime, I was feeling weird but couldn’t explain exactly why. That’s when I received the news that my cousin was killed with 10 shots in the back. I was devastated. Even though I knew that it was common for normal people to get killed in Brazil, I would never imagine that would happen to my family. After the funeral, I was scrolling through Facebook and felt like I had to get something out of my chest or I’d explode. I just wrote what I felt, pushed the publish button and went to bed. Surprisingly enough, over the next following days, I got over a dozen of likes and shares. My relatives read my post at the church meeting and said that many people cried afterward. At that point, I realized I might have a way with words and decided to take a step further and develop my craft. Since then, I’ve posted on Medium, Quora and applied for writing jobs on Upwork. I’m far from being the best writer but I can tell you one thing. There’s nothing holding you back from writing. You shouldn’t wait for a breakthrough, inspiration, circumstances or whatever to feel like writing. The only thing you should do right now is to pick a subject that interests you and write about it. After that, publish your work somewhere. That’s it! Simple, but not easy.

You learn to swim by swimming. You learn to paint by painting. You learn to play the piano by playing. And you learn to write, unsurprisingly, by writing. You gain the ability to structure words and ideas well by doing a whole lot of structuring your words and ideas poorly for a whole lot of words and ideas. You write word usements. They don’t work. You write more word usements. They still don’t work. You keep at it, and eventually you learn to use words good…err, use words well. That’s basically it. Of course, part of that process is feedback. You can’t tell the difference between word usements that are not so good and effective, insightful use of language if you don’t have any feedback. That means letting other folks see your word usements, either by showing people your work even when you think it’s not so good or by doing it in public places like Quora. But primarily, it’s a matter of practice. You learn to write by writing.

Create intrigue about the characters. When writing first chapters — of thrillers, especially — it’s fun to hint at trouble, lies, secrets, and scandal, but not give away everything. In my novel, The Heiresses, I start with the lines: “You know the Saybrooks. Everyone does.” This family is wealthy, NYC royalty, living a charmed life. But at the bottom of page one, things start to darken — I mention that every family member has a secret, and that they’re a bit cursed. Who isn’t tempted to read on about that? Use a setting as the inciting incident. I’ve already mentioned the “inciting incident” — the story beat that really gets the plot going. Sometimes, a place itself can cause or be the inciting incident. If it is, why not start the character there (or at the very least, on a mode of transport going there) to dive right in? A great example is in The Shining, where Jack is at the infamous Overlook Hotel interviewing for a new job. The reader thinks this is going to be a fresh start for him and his family… but of course, they’re wrong. Stephen King could have filled the first pages with exposition of Jack back in his old life, but starting the novel at the hotel — which is a character in itself — plunges the reader into the story. Up the stakes within the first few pages. In a thriller, it’s always great to start with a murder, a body found, or someone going missing — it sets up the problem and goal for the rest of the novel. In my series The Amateurs, the introduction is all about how main character Aerin Kelly’s sister, Helena, goes missing — and throughout the rest of the book, Aerin and the group of detectives she meets up with aim to figure out what happened.

Before you can begin writing, you need to know what you are writing about. First, look at the writing prompt or assignment topic. As you look at the prompt, note any key terms or repeated phrases because you will want to use those words in your response. Then ask yourself: On what topic am I supposed to be writing?What do I know about this topic already?If I don’t know how to respond to this assignment, where can I go to find some answers?What does this assignment mean to me? How do I relate to it?The best way to learn how to write is to start writing a paragraph.A paragraph has following parts: Topic Sentence: Give a short introduction about the topic that you are writing about. Actually, get a hold of whatever story you want to write.Think on what perspective you want to write it in. Let's take Harry Potter, for example. There are three places in a story you can start. 1. You write on and on until you finally reach the first Harry Potter book, which begins...2. Harry knows nothing about his parents. He still has a lot to learn, the future and his past included. Or...3. You can write as if everything has already happened. You can write in Harry's point of view of him recalling absolutely everything in his past. At this point, everything's decided and you know that the main character lives happily, or not-so-happily, ever after.  2 and 3 can go over and over again. There's always some past, but #1 means that there's nothing vital to your story in the past. You could write your books like J.K. did, or you could write as if it's all over. You could add so many sequels. They could all be Harry talking about his past, or, you could go back to Number two and put all of Harry's adventures in the past, write in #2's way with his children, or perhaps Hermione and Ron's children. So you've just got to stick your nose into the story and ruffle things around until you've found a place to start. You could put a dark past with the character and the villain already in progress. You could have them starting to become enemies. You could have them recollecting on how easy it was for them to hate each other.I hope I could help! And remember, there's only one perfect beginning. Make sure you've got the right one before it's written in stone.

What do you want to write? If it's something novel-length, start by sketching it out. What is your plot? What makes it an awesome story? Who are your characters? What are their traits and quirks? There are plenty of online resources (basically worksheets) for cementing your ideas. Write something: the opening, a major scene, the climax, whatever. Then put all of that aside for at least two weeks. When you come back with fresh energy and perspective, start writing it for real and don't stop. Write, rewrite, edit. If you come up with a totally new story while you’re writing (and you will), do the prewriting and get back to your story. If you want to write poetry or short stories, I advise you to read plenty of poetry and/or short stories and just start writing and writing. No matter what you do, talk to other writers. You can’t write from scratch. You have to have an idea! Surprisingly though, that isn’t the hard part. You can go outside at any moment in time and people-watch. That alone will give you an idea for a novel, not to mention the trial and error that is a part of your own life. Once you have an idea, you need to write. When someone says “from scratch” it often sounds to me as if they are afraid of writing something unworthy, more than they are afraid of the blank piece of paper in front of them. My advice here is to use brute force. That’s right. Bulldoze your way into the first few words, however shaky they may be. It’s important to forget any notions of what a great writer you are going to be and it’s equally important to assume you’re going to be bad at it. Whatever you do, don’t interfere with the scratching of the pen/pencil on paper. Don’t hesitate. Do not stop writing, even if you think what you wrote is gibberish. Even great writers use this method to get themselves out of a writing slump. You can use it to start…from scratch.
